MainHeading.Title: Transport Act, 1950 (Additional Powers) Order, 1961: Motion of Confirmation.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: I move:
That Seanad Éireann hereby confirms the Transport Act, 1950 (Additional Powers) Order, 1961.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport and Power (Mr. Childers) Erskine Hamilton Childers
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport and Power (Mr. Childers)
Speaker.P: The Transport Act, 1950 (Additional Powers) Order will not come into operation unless and until it has been confirmed by Resolution of each House of the Oireachtas.

The purpose of the Order is to confer on C.I.E. the power necessary to establish a subsidiary company to take over, operate and develop the Board's Great Southern hotels and catering services. The new company will be a private company set up under the Companies Acts and will have a share capital of £100,000, divided into 100,000 shares of £1 each. All of this capital will be taken up by C.I.E. The number of directors will be not more than six and their remuneration will be subject to my approval and the consent of the Minister for Finance. The Board of C.I.E. may appoint not more than three of themselves to be directors of the new company; the appointment of the remaining directors will be subject to my approval. The Chairman of C.I.E. for the time being, will be chairman of the company.

The Memorandum and Articles of Association of the new company and any alterations therein will be subject to my approval, but they cannot be finalised or the new company set up until the Oireachtas has approved this Order. The name of the new company which will be in Irish has not been finally settled but the Board intend to continue the use of the name Great Southern Hotels to which very valuable goodwill attaches. The report and accounts of the company will be presented annually to the Oireachtas.

MainHeading.P: The new company will take over the seven Great Southern hotels by way of conveyance or lease. It will also take over the Board's hotels department headquarters at 141 Thomas Street, Dublin. In addition, the company will operate the various catering services at present provided by the Board on dining cars, at station refreshment rooms, at Busarus, and on the Aran steamer and Shannon pleasure boats.

The extent of the business undertaken by these hotels and services can be judged from the figures quoted in the Board's financial accounts for recent years. For the year ended 31st March, 1960 receipts from the hotels and refreshment services totalled £885,000 whereas expenditure, including provision for superannuation, amounted to £824,000 in the same year. In the year ended 31st March, 1961, receipts amounted to £991,000 approximately and expenditure, again including provision for superannuation, to about £915,000.

It is not the intention that the company will receive any direct or indirect financial subsidy from the Exchequer apart from whatever grants or other assistance it may be entitled to receive in common with other hotel companies, for example, through Bord Fáilte. To the extent that such grants will not be sufficient to finance future development it is the intention that the company will finance development through capital raised on the security of its own assets or alternatively through borrowing guaranteed by C.I.E.

The number of staff involved varies from about 550 in the winter season to 900 in the summer season. There has been full consultation between the Board and the Unions involved in regard to the transfer of staff to the new company. Transferred staff will retain their existing rights to superannuation benefits and redundancy compensation and I have given an undertaking that amending legislation in order to provide for retention of such rights by the staff concerned, will be introduced.

The proposal to establish a separate company for the Board's hotels and catering services represents a welcome decentralisation of management and control. The operation of hotels has little in common with transport problems and it is desirable that the higher management of C.I.E. should be able to concentrate on the difficult transport problems they still have to face. Conversely, the hotels and catering services can have the undivided attention of specialised management staff and this will be all the more important as a major scheme of improvement and extension of the hotels is now under way. There will be room on the new Board for new blood with specialised qualifications.
I recommend that the House should confirm this Order and I am sure that the House will join with me in wishing the new company every success.

Speaker.P: I have listened very carefully to the Minister to see if I could get some understandable reason for this proposal. I would remind the Seanad that the Minister has confirmed in what he has said that C.I.E. have been making a success of the hotel section of the undertaking. I am not aware of any difficulty experienced by C.I.E. in running the hotels efficiently and profitably as a section of public transport. The tendency in C.I.E. is for top management to delegate authority and responsibility down the line, which is a very good thing. Top management in C.I.E. is not now involved in a mass of minutiae. Top management can now concentrate on the major task of making a success of public transport. I think they are right, and I think they are doing a good job in that respect.

I cannot understand why the hotels section as such cannot continue to be run efficiently and profitably as part of the general public transport organisation. I note that the Minister said that it is proposed that the Chairman of C.I.E. will be the chairman of this subsidiary company. It would appear, therefore, that the Chairman will not have his task lightened or made easier by the setting up of this subsidiary company. He will be chairman of the new company as well as being chairman of the main Board of C.I.E.

MainHeading.P: The experience over the years has been that the C.I.E. hotels are better managed and more profitable when they are integrated in the undertaking rather than when run as a separate entity, apart from the general organisation. Some years ago, the hotels were farmed out to an English hotel company. They ran hotels for the G.S.R. That arrangement was, however, abandoned and since then, the hotels have been organised and operated as a section of public transport. As a section of public transport, they have been more profitable. They have provided a better service to the economy generally and a better service to the tourist industry. Up to now, I have failed to hear any good economic reason to justify the proposal before the House.

The people with whom I am connected are naturally suspicious that this may be the first step in hiving off a remunerative section of our nationalised public transport organisation. Certainly it seems to be one step away from public control. The Minister has told us that the share capital of the new company will amount to some £100,000, all of which will be held by C.I.E. Can the Minister assure us that all the shares will continue to be held by C.I.E.? Can he give us a guarantee that in the years to come, the shares will remain in the hands of the subsidiary company? Will there be some other arrangement in two or three years time? The shares might pass into private hands.

We start on a process of hiving off a paying section of public transport, while leaving the uneconomic and unremunerative part of the organisation to the taxpayers to support. In Britain, the policy of the Tory Government is— it is certainly the policy advocated by supporters of that Government—to hive off all the profitable sections of the British Transport Commission to private enterprise; give them over to private enterprise because it is something on which one can make money, but leave the railways, which do not pay, to the taxpayers. The hotels and refreshment rooms on which a profit can be made are handed over to private enterprise. Naturally, we are suspicious that this might be the first step here towards hiving off a profitable section of a nationalised organisation to private enterprise.

As Senators are aware, that has been advocated in regard to the E.S.B. When it was possible that the E.S.B. might lose money, people said it was all right to have the E.S.B. as a nationalised undertaking. When there was risk involved, it was all right. Now that it has become remunerative, it is all right to hand it over to private enterprise. Can the Minister assure us that this is not a first step towards hiving off a remunerative section of public transport? Can he assure us that all the equity share capital of the subsidiary will continue to be held by C.I.E.?

I am surprised at this proposal from another aspect. Aer Lingus, another nationalised transport undertaking, will enter the hotel business. It has joined with other organisations to build hotels. I should have thought that, if the intention were to have a hotel subsidiary as such, it might well be a hotel subsidiary which would deal not alone with the hotels of C.I.E. but also with the hotel business into which Aer Lingus contemplates entering.

Having said that, and having admitted that I am suspicious and cannot completely welcome this move, I would say that from the trade union point of view, while opposed to the proposal in principle, we will be quite ready to co-operate and continue to make a success of the hotel section of C.I.E. Certain problems will, of course, arise. The Minister has dealt with some of them. I trust he will excuse me if I go through them in some detail now, so that we may have some firm assurances as to what will happen in regard to the staff.

The clerical staff of the hotels subsidiary have, in common with the rest of the clerical staff of C.I.E., the safeguards of the 1924 legislation, inasmuch as their terms and conditions of service must be the subject of negotiation with the trade unions representing these people. In other words, C.I.E. are obliged to fix terms and conditions of service in relation to certain groups of employees through the medium of negotiation with the trade unions concerned. Can we be assured now that that sort of cover will continue to be extended to staff which had that cover up to now as part of the general establishment of C.I.E.?

Another question is the recruitment of staff. Since 1924, Parliament has laid it down in successive transport legislation that appointment to the clerical staff of public transport should be by way of competitive examination. In other words, appointment should be on the basis of what you know rather than whom you know. I think that is an excellent principle and I am sure every Senator will agree with me. I think that principle should continue to apply to clerical staff recruited in the future by this subsidiary to our public transport organisation. The hotels staff are a specialised staff. The clerical staff working in the hotels are part of the general clerical establishment of C.I.E. They have common recruitment, as I said, through competitive examination, common conditions of service. They are interchangeable between various departments. They happen, for the time being, to be employed in this particular section of the undertaking.

I know C.I.E. would wish that they would go with the job; in other words, that there would be no upset, that the people who are doing the job at the moment in the hotels section should go with the job to the hotels subsidiary. I also would wish that that should happen. Whilst being opposed in principle, as I said, we are quite willing to co-operate to make a success of the set-up, if it is to be that way.

Of course, they are being given an option to go with the job or else stay in C.I.E. and be absorbed into some other section of the undertaking, but, if they go with the job, they do need certain protection. They are part of a fairly big establishment at the moment, the nationalised public transport organisation. They happen to be working in one section of it. When this goes through, they will be employees of a comparatively small organisation, a subsidiary company of C.I.E.

C.I.E. have another subsidiary company, the transport subsidiary, but here it is not thought necessary or desirable that they should have a separate salaried establishment. They are part of the general clerical establishment of C.I.E. They simply happen to be working in that particular section of the transport subsidiary. For my part, I cannot see why a similar arrangement should not operate, why the clerical staff should not continue to be part of the general clerical establishment and simply be working for the hotels subsidiary and have their salaries, etc., charged against the subsidiary. That, I believe, is not the intention. It is the intention that they will be quite a separate and distinct establishment with their own methods of recruitment for the future.

They have, as the Minister said, superannuation rights at the present time. I think the Minister said in his introductory remarks that he would be prepared to guarantee the superannuation rights, if they choose to go into this new hotels subsidiary. I do not know how he will guarantee them, whether it would be necessary to introduce legislation to do that and, if so, I am sure the Minister and his Department will, in accordance with the usual good practice, arrange for prior consultation with the trade union representatives.

The Minister also mentioned the question of compensation. This, I think, is a rather difficult problem. We have previously found a satisfactory solution to this problem for a section of staff going with the job to a new undertaking. We solved it in connection with the setting up of the Dundalk Engineering Works. Up to then, it was part of the Great Northern Railway as such. It was desirable that the staff should, if possible, go with the job to this new company. The salaried staff had the option of going over or coming into C.I.E. and a very satisfactory and workable arrangement was made in regard to the staff who went over to the Dundalk Engineering Works.

I would wish that the staff who may opt—and I hope all of them who are wanted will opt—to go to the hotels subsidiary should have similar cover in regard to compensation. Again, I think it will require legislation and I hope we can have adequate consultation and agreement on the matter before the legislation is introduced. In the meantime, of course, the hotels subsidiary is being set up and I think the arrangements will be that the staff will be seconded to this subsidiary until the necessary legislation can be introduced.

As I said at the start, I am objecting in principle to this idea of setting up a subsidiary company to operate hotels. I do not think it is justified. I think C.I.E. have made a very good job of managing and operating the hotels under the existing arrangement. I cannot understand why that could not continue. If there is to be a hotels subsidiary, I cannot understand, either, why it should not be dealt with in the same way as the transport subsidiary is dealt with at the moment. Having said that, if it is to be as the Minister and C.I.E. want it, having opposed it to that extent, we—and I speak for the trade unions generally in this matter—will be ready to continue to co-operate to make a success of the hotels subsidiary company.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: I am certain the Minister will be able to give to Senator Murphy the assurances he is looking for but I think Senator Murphy was very right to ask for them, because, obviously, it is a matter upon which there would be public concern if it were to be thought that this was merely a matter of allowing a public company in two phases to become a private company for some of its more profitable sections. However, I do not believe that is the case. I think the Minister will be able to give every assurance on that point, it having been raised.

There is another point. Personally, I would welcome the new suggestion. On general grounds of efficiency, it seems to me, it could be best defended because the hotels section, if you like, of C.I.E. can be virtually autonomous within the company and will be better able to plan, to organise and to direct under that large degree of autonomy. Also, of course, it will not suffer to the same extent as if it were merely a portion of the larger company from fluctuations in the financial situation, for instance, of the larger company.

MainHeading.P: Roche's Hotel in Glengarriff was bought up by C.I.E. in order to be demolished and replaced by a large luxury hotel. It is widely stated there that C.I.E. bought the hotel for a large sum of money. The hotel was on a site in Glengarriff which is certainly the best in the whole place, in probably the finest beauty spot in Ireland, without exception. Roche's Hotel happened to be just at the right place. It is said it was bought at great expense and, at considerable further expense, it was demolished, stone taken from stone. The hotel is no longer there. It was completely flattened. This was an unhappy period in the history of C.I.E., financially. They had not got the money to build what they intended to build in its stead and so they sold it at a good price to the highest bidder, the proprietor of a rival hotel, thereby ensuring that there probably will never again be a hotel on that site which, clearly, would be a very active and potent rival to all the other hotels there.

I may be wrong—I am open to correction if I am—but I would say that as a result of the hotels section of C.I.E. being too intimately connected with C.I.E. itself, it would be too swiftly affected by squalls and storms of financial losses. I would hope that that kind of situation will not arise under the new company about which I am quite confident the Minister can give us the assurances Senator Murphy has asked for.

Speaker.P: There is just one question. Is it proposed to give this company power to acquire further hotels? I would certainly be against any such powers without further legislation.
Why? They provide a very good service for the tourist industry.

First, I should like to thank Senator Murphy for his cautious and critical but nevertheless constructive approach to this Order. I should say—and I think Senator Murphy knows already—that the trade unions are in complete accord with C.I.E. in regard to all the arrangements that will be made for the staff and all those matters have been already settled.
But not necessarily in accord with the general principle of setting up subsidiary companies.

As the Senator says, without necessarily being in accord with the actual principle. As far as the decentralisation of the hotel services of C.I.E. is concerned, I thoroughly believe in it. I must beg to differ from the Senator in regard to that. I hope this decentralisation and the introduction of new blood at the top level will bring new ideas and new techniques into the hotel and catering car administration.

The hotel business is a different business from the transport business. Motorists come to hotels as well as those who travel by train and bus. While co-ordination with the C.I.E. rail and transport services will be fully maintained, I think there will be a further and more rapid development of the C.I.E. hotel chain. I think improvement can also be made in regard to the catering services. There will be plans for buffet rooms in the various stations and improvements of all kinds to brighten up not only the hotel world but the world of C.I.E. in so far as the travellers making use of the services need refreshment and need good cheer en route.

There are still only seven hotels within the C.I.E. system. There is probably room for more. It should be noted that there has been a tremendous delay in the expansion of Irish A and even B class hotels since the end of the war. I remember we had something like 14,000 bedroom units in the country. Up to 1957 there had only been added fewer than 700 rooms with bath to that entire structure. As a result of Bord Fáilte grants and loans, a speed-up is taking place. C.I.E. have already had successful experience with their hotels. I believe the new management will be able to partake in the expansion in a more successful way as a result of the regionalisation.

MainHeading.P: Next, I should say that the shares of the hotel subsidiary cannot be transferred without my consent. Whereas I do not agree at all with the attitude of the Tory Conservatives, who appear to actually want to “hive off” completely the profit-making parts of the British Transport Commission, I do agree with that part of the White Paper published recently by Sir Ernest Marples, the Minister for Transport, in which he asked for more regionalisation and getting away from an enormously overstaffed central complexus in relation to the transport system. That is not against, if you like to put it this way, the tradition of nationalisation, whether conceived by socialists or whether conceived by pragmatists, as it is in this country. The idea of regionalisation is possible, whether one is a socialist or a pragmatist, believing in State promotion of business, as we do here. We have very few people here who actually believe in socialism for socialism's sake, whereas we have indulged in the formation of State companies where we thought the public weal demanded it.

With regard to Senator Murphy's suggestion that C.I.E. should run the hotels which are to be connected with Aer Rianta Teo., I should say that is a project mooted by a hotel subsidiary of Pan-American Airways and it is a combine of Pan-American Airways, the Government and certain substantial private shareholders—well-known public men—and Aer Rianta to provide hotels which will help to bring more tourists, largely from the United States, to Ireland and provide them with the kind of American accommodation to which they are accustomed and to which everybody seems to be becoming accustomed as the years go by. It is because of the treble, so to speak, interest of Pan-American Airways and our own air service, the Government and private interests that the hotels are developing in that particular way. I do not think it means that the Government wish to stop the C.I.E. subsidiary from developing hotels on their own, from expanding and increasing the accommodation in their existing hotels and from building others, if they so desire.

The clerical officers who are transfered to the C.I.E. hotels subsidiary will carry with them all the rights they have derived by law into their new positions. The conditions of recruitment of new staff are a matter for the new company set up, but I imagine that the conditions for recruitment will be suitable and of the highest standard. I can hardly believe that six directors, of whom four are C.I.E. directors, will conduct the enterprise in a way that would be to the disadvantage of the right sort of people who want to become employees.

Speaker.P: What does the Minister mean by the right sort of people?
People appointed by recruiting methods, which should have the effect of enlisting deserving persons.
By competitive examination?
I am sure the system of staff recruitment will redound to the credit of the hotel company. It is to be within the power of the company to provide recruiting arrangements such as they think fit.
But Parliament did not say that in respect of C.I.E. and its predecessors.

I do not think there is any reason to suppose there will be a change. Once a company is owned by another State company, I should think the company would be slow to adopt methods which could result in public criticism, suspicions of political influence or influence by individual directions or anything of that kind.
That is not the point.

The Senator knows very well, I think, that the tradition will be maintained. I understand that the fringe benefits enjoyed by the staff will continue. As I indicated earlier, there will be a separate superannuation scheme, for which legislation will be introduced, enabling the staff transferred to the hotels subsidiary to enjoy the superannuation rights and the inherited and accumulated pension rights they have enjoyed under C.I.E.

MainHeading.P: As far as redundancy is concerned, the staff have made it clear that they wish to have their redundancy rights applied to them when they are transferred to the hotels subsidiary. But I think that Senator Murphy and the House generally know the conditions of Section 4 of the Transport Act, 1958, that those compensation benefits apply only under certain safeguards and the same conditions will apply to such staff as wish to claim redundancy rights and who are transferred to the hotels subsidiary.

In reply to Senator Sheehy Skeffington, I cannot give him the history of the Roche's Hotel site. I do not happen to know it. But I can assure the Senator that as soon as the separate hotels subsidiary is set up, it should not be impeded by any fluctuating fortunes—and we hope there will not be any fluctuation—of the main C.I.E. organisation and that there will be a very individual attitude on the part of the directors in regard to hotel development. The only thing I remember about Roche's Hotel was that at the time it seemed to people who were not forward looking that it might be lunatic to erect a £1 million luxury hotel for American type travellers in what appeared to people at that time to be a country so undeveloped and with such an inferiority complex about itself that such enterprises would look ridiculous.

It seems to me that if that hotel had been built, it would have been very profitably engaged in the past eight years. Under the Programme for Economic Expansion, we have tended to get away from the small-minded conceptions which affected this country not only regarding hotels but such matters as transatlantic aircraft. We have got away from those ideas, so I think it is unlikely that the new hotel company will wish to draw in its horns when the tourist turnover is increasing at the rate of something like £3,000,000 a year and when Bord Fáilte are evidently having considerable success in drawing visitors to this country, and when our attributes such as our uncongested spaces and good road system are inevitably going to draw more and more people from a world where beaches on the European coasts for literally hundreds of miles are packed from May to September. I hope the hotel company will have a forward-looking point of view and with their new-found powers, will be able to assist in the development of the tourist programme in no small measure.

Speaker.P: Could I ask the Minister a question? He got away from the point about the capital. Can he assure the House that the capital of the subsidiary will continue to be wholly owned by C.I.E.?

I can assure him that would require my consent and, I think, the consent of the Minister for Finance. Many of the main sections of the articles of association would be subjected to the same kind of control by the Minister for Finance as are the articles of other companies.
I know, but will it continue to be owned wholly by C.I.E.?

One of the conditions is that the memorandum and articles will be subject to the approval of the Minister and the Minister for Finance. No alteration can be made therein without the Minister's approval. That provides a control of the share structure.
That is why I am asking.
And any increase in the capital will be subject to the Minister for Finance. The approval of the Minister will be required for any transfer of shares. That covers the point.
The Minister is assuring us he can control it but not that it will be continued to be wholly owned by C.I.E.
Question put and agreed to.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - County Cork School Inquiry.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: I asked per mission to raise on the Adjournmen tonight the unsatisfactory nature of the recently-held inquiry into the Raharoon, County Cork, national school. In my opinion, the Oireachtas, if it were fully informed of the circumstances, would be gravely disturbed over certain features of this whole case, its background, and the holding of the inquiry in such a way as to make it appear that its chief purpose was to cover up certain facts that were emerging, to conceal as much as possible of the evidence and to provide a pretext for the avoidance of action on the part of the Minister for Education, which should have been taken long ago.

Now, the prologue, as it were, to the inquiry arises out of a case reported in the Cork Examiner of January 25th this year. It arises out of a case in which £25 was awarded to a 10-year old schoolgirl and I quote from the Cork Examiner:—
who claimed that she had been injured as a result of severe punishment inflicted on her by a teacher, was awarded £25 with costs and expenses...

On July 1,1960, the defendant as alleged, assaulted the girl by hitting her with great force with a cane on her right arm and elbow and subsequently administering 11 heavy strokes with the cane on her hands. On July 4 and 5 the defendant further assaulted the girl by giving her four and five heavy blows with the cane on the hands.

As a result of the punishment the girl claimed that she had suffered from much shock and pain and the palm of her right hand was red and swollen. She found difficulty in raising her right hand above her head because of pain in her shoulder. In addition, she was much frightened and suffered from fine tremors of her hands and mouth. She also sustained physical damage, frequently starting in her sleep and waking up crying and frequently breaking into tears when school was mentioned.

The girl further claimed that when, after an absence of 14 weeks, she returned to school on October 10 the defendant again assaulted her and marked her hand with a stroke of a cane administered with great physical violence.
It emerges further that she goes to this school with four of her brothers and five sisters: a large number of the same family going to the school. She gave evidence to the effect:

MainHeading.P: The master had a stick in his hand and he turned around and gave me a crack of it on the right arm. That hurt me and I was crying, and then he caught my hand and gave me ten other slaps, He went up to his own desk and I was sitting in my desk crying with the pain in my hand and he came down after me and made me hold out my other hand and he gave me another slap.

Speaker.P: The Senator is now going outside the scope of the motion. The motion refers to the unsatisfactory nature of the recently-held Raharoon national school inquiry. This is not an inquiry into court matters.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: With your permission, I should like to establish the fact that the inquiry arises out of the bringing to court under the School Attendance Act of the parents of this little girl who refused to send her back because of this——
I think the House appreciates why the inquiry was set up.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: If you will permit me, I should like to quote what the judge said because I think it establishes what the feeling of the court was.
I cannot see the relevance of what the judge said to the inquiry into the Raharoon school.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: I submit to your ruling, although I suggest that it is legitimate to establish the basis upon which the whole inquiry rests.
I have allowed the Senator a good deal of liberty so far but I think from now on he must concern himself with the unsatisfactory nature of the recently held Raharoon school inquiry.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: The House is aware that the inquiry was an inquiry into allegations which were made at a subsequent court case in which Mr. Michael Hurley was brought to court on April 7th, 1961, for failing to send three of his children to school, one being this girl. Allegations were made during this second court case into which the Minister found it necessary to inquire and he set up the inquiry.
It is the inquiry which is under consideration.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: I agree. I felt it necessary to establish the background, but I mention the fact that the parents of these children failed to send three of their children back to the school, and that they were then summoned for non-attendance. During that school attendance case, certain allegations were made which this inquiry is expected to be investigating. I feel it is directly relevant to the inquiry to mention the terms of reference of the inquiry, which were to inquire into allegations made during this school attendance case which the district justice adjourned in the first place “to see if anything would emanate from the Department of Education.” Eventually, that school attendance case was adjourned twice successively for a month each time. A question was asked in the Dáil and this is how the inquiry came to be set up. On 4th of May this year, Deputy Dr. Browne asked the Minister for Education, and I quote from column 1778 of the Official Reports:—

if he is aware that parents of children who were assaulted at national schools have been summoned under the School Attendance Act, because they will not allow their children to return to school to the teacher guilty of assaulting them; and what action he intends taking in such instances.
The Minister replied:
I am not aware of any specific instances where parents have been summoned under the School Attendance Act in circumstances as stated.

Although in fact this is a month after the case of April 7th which was specifically adjourned by the district justice as he himself said, “to see if anything would emanate from the Department of Education” but the Minister was kept in humiliating ignorance of that fact. The Report continues:

MainHeading.P: Dr. Browne: If I give the Minister an instance of this kind will he be prepared to use whatever influence he has to see that the child is not asked against the wishes of the child's parents, to go back to the school where the assault occurred?
Dr. Hillery: I am quite prepared fully to investigate any incident such as that mentioned by the Deputy.

Speaker.P: Again, I want to remind the Senator that this motion is concerned with the unsatisfactory nature of the recently held Raharoon national school inquiry. The other matters are not relevant.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: With respect, the inquiry had to be set up——
The House understands that the enquiry was set up and recently held.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: That is the way in which it was set up, and that is the purpose for which it was set up. The case into which the inquiry purports to be inquiring is that certain allegations were made about conditions in the school being such that the father refused to send three of his children back to it. He stated in court that there was an improvement in the school after the case against the teacher, but things “had gone back” afterwards. The case was then adjourned a second time in order to allow the teacher to appear in court, which he did not do. Further allegations were made at this third sitting of the District Court, allegations which this inquiry has been asked by the Minister to look into. One of the allegations was that the teacher had hit another child on an amputated finger, and he had admitted he did it in order that this child would “not have an inferiority complex.” That was admitted by the teacher himself.

MainHeading.P: In early June, the School Attendance Act case was finally settled by the application to the father, Mr. Hurley, of the Probation Act. Mr. Hurley was advised to send the children back to the school, the teacher not having taken the offered opportunity to state his case to the court. In my contention, it was the clear duty of the Minister long before this to make an inquiry into the whole situation, but I suggest that it was only then that he decided that he himself should take some action, and he set up this inquiry. He wrote a letter to Mr. and Mrs. Hurley and other parents informing them that he was having the matter investigated; that the inquiry would be held on 4th and 5th of July, and that any parents who were concerned would have the right to be legally represented at the inquiry at their own expense.

I am referring to the Minister's letter to Mr. and Mrs. Hurley in relation to the evidence given at the School Attendance case—the case out of which the inquiry arose. I feel that it was legitimate for these parents to assume, on the basis of that letter, that they were being invited to attend; that they would be heard if they attended, and that they would be admitted to the hearing. Consequently, one of the unsatisfactory features of the case, to my mind, is that they were not, in fact, heard and that they were not, in fact, admitted to the hearing. Also, they were told that they could be legally represented but entirely at their own expense.

On July, 4th and 5th, the inquiry was held. I asked the Minister's permission, owing to what seemed to me to be the disturbing features of the case, to be allowed to attend the inquiry myself. I asked in the following terms on 24th July, 1961:

I have seen it reported in the press that you intend to hold a formal inquiry into allegations about the National School in Raharoon, Co. Cork, on July 4th next. As a member of the Oireachtas, I am interested to know how such inquiries are conducted, and I wish, therefore, to request that you give me your permission to be present at this inquiry as an observer. In addition to my interest in the general procedure, I am concerned about the facts in this particular case, and I am doubly anxious to be allowed to be present on this occasion.
I received a reply, first of all, from the office to say that the Minister was away. Three days later, on 29th June, I got this letter from the Minister's Secretary.
With further reference to your letter of 24th instant relating to the proposed formal inquiry at Raharoon School, I am to inform you that all such inquiries are conducted in private——
That is one of the points that seem to me to be unsatisfactory. The letter continues:
The only persons——
and I stress the word “only”——

permitted to be present are the Inspectors conducting the inquiry, the School Manager, the teacher or teachers concerned, the legal representative of the teacher or teachers, a representative of the Irish National Teachers' Organisation, the parents and children concerned——
That apparently is in theory only, because only a select few were in fact to be permitted to be present. The letter goes on:
the legal representatives of the parents and such other persons as are being called as witnesses.

In view of this and in view of the fact that you have no locus standi in relation to the case in question, the Minister must express his regret that he cannot give you permission to be present at the inquiry.

In other words, a member of the Oireachtas is excluded from being present. The mere fact of being a member of the Oireachtas is not enough to admit one to the star-chamber investigation under the Department of Education, which has to be so hush-hush, so private and so secret that not even the press or a member of Parliament, or not even the parents of the children who had suffered the conditions from which the whole inquiry sprang could be admitted.
Let me quote from page five of today's Irish Times. Deputy Corish is quoted as putting a question in the Dáil yesterday. The extract from the Irish Times is as follows:

Mr. B. Corish (Labour) asked the Minister for Education in the Dáil yesterday whether he would consider reversing his decision not to admit members of the Houses of the Oireachtas to formal inquiries held by his Department; and, if not, whether in view of the fact that he was responsible to the Dáil, he would make available to the members of both Houses a full and comprehensive verbatim report of the proceedings at such inquiries.

Dr. Hillery said that the purpose of a formal inquiry into charges preferred against a teacher was to ascertain facts so as to enable him to come to a decision as to whether the teacher concerned had been guilty of conduct unbefitting a teacher.

“These inquiries are non-statutory,” said the Minister, “and since they involve the giving of evidence by schoolchildren and the voluntary attendance of a number of persons for the purpose of giving evidence I am satisfied that the general interest is best served by the presence of only those persons directly concerned in the matter. I am also satisfied that my responsibility to Dáil Éireann does not require me to supply members of the House with detailed information concerning administrative inquiries instituted by me.”

Again, I find that profoundly unsatistory. The members of Dáil Éireann and the Seanad are not only all automatically excluded, but they will not be given any information as to what took place. I note that in the same news item the Schoolchildren's Protection Organisation in Dublin is reported as issuing a statement which says:

“Not only were Mr. and Mrs. M. Hurley and their children refused permission to state their grievances at this inquiry, although they waited in attendance for two whole days in the expectation of being admitted, but the doctor who had examined and medically treated some of the children, following beatings at the school, came to the inquiry at great inconvenience, and was also not permitted to give his evidence before the inquiry officials.
“On the other hand, some parents who did not wish to make any complaint about the treatment of their children at this school were permitted to attend and submit statements.”

There again, we find it stated that Mr. and Mrs. Hurley were excluded. The doctor himself, who came at personal inconvenience and expense, was excluded. Yet some parents were admitted. Why were these parents admitted? Because they had come to say that everything was rosy in the garden, and that they were quite happy about the school? Only one type of evidence was wanted. It is quite legitimate, of course, for those who have such a view of the school, if there are any such, to come and give evidence, but to exclude others and to make such a selection of witnesses, seems to me a disgraceful procedure in this closed, hush-hush inquiry which purports to be seeking the facts.

Mr. and Mrs. Hurley were allowed to wait two days in the other room, and were not admitted at all, and yet the Minister for Education wrote to them specially, and in his letter to me, which I have already quoted, referred to the fact that such people would be permitted to be present, “the parents and children concerned, the legal representatives of the parents”, and so on which seemed to me to give promise of fair play. Finally, after the inquiry had closed, he said yesterday, in the Dáil, as I have quoted, that no information would be given about the findings of this inquiry.

Therefore, in view of all these facts, I decided to raise the matter on the Adjournment. It seemed to me that the circumstances of this whole inquiry were profoundly unsatisfactory, profoundly disturbing, first of all, because justice in such circumstances is not seen to be done; secondly, because some of the parents and children were excluded, among them Mr. and Mrs. Hurley and the boys who had gone back to the school after this little girl was beaten, and according to their evidence, were deliberately neglected by the teacher; thirdly, because the doctor was not admitted; fourthly because all members of the Oireachtas apparently are excluded from all such inquiries; fifthly, because the parents were graciously allowed by the Minister to pay for their own legal representation, but without permission to be present themselves; and finally because all the findings of the inquiry when it is completed are to be kept entirely secret.

I am quite sure that the Minister will eventually make a statement saying that a “suitable investigation has been made and appropriate action taken,” without revealing a single fact to the public, or the Dáil, or the parents concerned. The facts as accepted as having been proved in the Circuit Court last January—many were admitted by the teacher himself— seemed more than sufficient to show that this particular teacher, a young man of 27, should not be in charge of children in a national school. I believe, therefore, that the Minister should have taken strong action long ago. He has done nothing, and now he blandly holds this type of highly unsatisfactory inquiry. The public can only come to the conclusion that the whole purpose is to cover-up, to conceal and distort the facts, and give one more officially organised excuse for masterly ministerial inactivity. The whole case, in my submission to the House, is a disgraceful and abominable one in many ways, but even worse, in my contention, is the Minister's conniving at the whole process of concealment implicit in the methods employed behind the shield of this simulacrum of an inquiry for it cannot be taken as a genuine inquiry at all. I find that this connivance is nothing short of scandalous, and it is greatly to be regretted that the Minister has not found it possible to be present tonight, nor appointed somebody of ministerial rank to hear this matter being raised on the Adjournment, and to answer for him.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: Senator Sheehy Skeffington has made a valiant effort to confuse the issue by the introduction of bogeymen. He has endeavoured to make members of the Seanad shiver by saying that the Oireachtas should be greatly disturbed, that there was a star chamber investigation, a closed hush-hush inquiry, and referring to a whole process of concealment and finally the awful crime that not even Senator Sheehy Skeffington was admitted.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: Or Senator Mullins.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: I did not ask to be admitted. I have implicit confidence in the Minister's inquiry.

The Senator has made a valiant attempt to confuse the issue and it might be well to bring him back to earth. The only things at issue in the formal inquiry were matters alleged to have occurred since Mr. Hurley took court proceedings against the teacher. All the matters previous to Mr. Hurley's court action against the teacher had not only been before that court but were the subject of investigation by the Minister and the Minister had taken appropriate action as a result of that investigation.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: What did he do?

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: Accordingly, the matters which fell to be investigated at the formal inquiry which worry the Senator were the allegations reported to have been made by Mr. Hurley in evidence at the hearing of the summons against him for failing to send his children to school, that the teacher refused to teach Mr. Hurley's children who had given evidence against him in the original case; secondly, the case made by Mrs. O'Sullivan that the teacher had refused to teach her children; and thirdly, Mrs. O'Sullivan's further complaint of excessive punishment of her child by the teacher.

The inspector in charge of the inquiry examining the roll book of the school observed that, since the first court, the Hurley children who had been in the class taught by the teacher whose conduct was the subject of inquiry had not attended the school.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: According to the records of the teacher.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: Accordingly, the reported allegation that since the first court the teacher had refused to teach these children had no substance.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: According to the teacher.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: The teacher could not have refused to teach children who were not there. The inspector, therefore, ruled out Mr. Hurley's reported allegation as having no substance and so he had no occasion to admit Mr. Hurley.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: The teacher treated them as though they were absent.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: Since there was no reason for an allegation of ill-treatment since the court proceedings, there was no reason for medical evidence. A vast majority of local parents with children in the class of the teacher concerned asked to be allowed to state their side of the story regarding the teacher. The inspector who was inquiring into whether the teacher's conduct was such as befitted a teacher allowed—quite rightly, in my opinion—the representatives of these parents to give evidence.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: It may be asked, as Senator Sheehy Skeffington did, why did the Minister order a formal inquiry in the second instance. He did so because of the grave action that would be necessary on his part if these further charges were well-founded.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: Why did he write to Mr. and Mrs. Hurley?

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: In ordering the inquiry, he was not, however, engaged in the type of public witch hunt— known as MacCarthyism in America —which seems to appeal to Senator Sheehy Skeffington, according to his speech tonight. In fact, the inquiry which he ordered was a non-statutory inquiry. There is no provision for a statutory inquiry in such a case. These non-statutory inquiries are not privileged and it will be clear accordingly why it could not be held in public. Being a non-public inquiry, the only persons who should be allowed to be present were those with a locus standi in the matter, and, with all respect to Senator Sheehy Skeffington and to this alleged organisation with its non-stop campaign with letters in the Evening Mail, I do not think he would have a locus standi.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: No member of Parliament would be admitted.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: The Minister carries responsibility towards all the persons concerned and included in that responsibility is the duty to protect any or all of them including the teacher——

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: Certainly.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: ——from what may be wildly irresponsible charges. It is no function of the Minister, whether a person is innocent or guilty, to engage in a public execution of a person's character as appears to be adopted by Senator Sheehy Skeffington.

Incidentally, I notice that the second newspaper to which the Senator gave his reply to the Minister was wiser than the first. It omitted his libellous statement about two other teachers who were not concerned at all in this case.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Sheehy Skeffington Dr. Sheehy Skeffington
Speaker.P: I libelled no one. What I said had been established in the courts.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: I do not think the Oireachtas need be unduly disturbed by the conclusions of Senator Sheehy Skeffington.
The Seanad adjourned at 9.5 p.m. until Wednesday, 19th July, 1961.
